div.p: Greetings and best wishes. For the things you sent, I thank you, dear brother, especially for the decrees of the council, which I am returning; for last week I received both the index of heretics and the decrees of the Council of Trent published by the pope, with a brief apostolic preface and elegantly printed by Paolo Manuzio in Venice; I received them from Padua from my old friend Mr. Engelbert Milander from Hesse, who may also be known to you. But I have not seen the disputation of that Cardillus of yours, nor have I heard anything about it before. Here, here, if you please, you may take the opportunity to respond to it diligently, relevantly, and briefly. If copies are sent to Frankfurt, I will inform Froschauer.

The same person said he would take care of Erastus's business; he dealt with the people of Locarno; they replied that they would bring it from Milan, but not for less than 15 gold coins. If I write to Erastus, I will remember your advice.

The decrees of the Council of Trent were also previously printed in Cologne, from where I also obtained them. What I have from Bern and Geneva, I am sending to you here, so that you may see that even in many matters I never forget you; be careful not to spread them rashly. If it seems convenient to you, return this writing to me; if not, keep it.
The letter in Latin is from Beza to me.
I have not yet received any definite response from the people of Bern; when I do, I will write more fully.
Now farewell together with your wife, children, and our friends; all of mine greet you. Zurich, July 28, 1564.
To the most excellent man Mr. Johannes Fabricius, minister of the church of Chur, my most esteemed and dear lord and brother. Chur.
